unPrism: Simple Secure Comms at Home

As the LEAP project says, democracy of all shapes and sizes is meaningless without the right to whisper. All democracies currently comprise groups of widely divergent levels of resource and power (think Rupert Murdoch or Bill Gates vs. a homeless person, or a million other less extreme examples). It is impossible, in these circumstances, to remove the ability of the powerful to coerce the powerless. As a consequence, if the powerful have universal access to communication, democracy is broken.

Now consider Edward Snowden's revelations about Prism, Tempora and related programmes. It turns our that all your email is bcc'd to BoredYoungSpies@nsa.gov, and that you're a Facebook friend of NoSenseOfHumour@gchq.gov.uk The NSA (in partnership with the UK's GCHQ), collects 'nearly everything a user does on the internet'. Not only do the powerful have unfettered access to our communications, but so do tens of thousands of contractors (and anyone who hacks or bribes their way into their systems). And it seems pretty certain that whatever dirty business the US (and UK) are wrapped up in is also going on in China and a bunch of other countries.

One of the worst consequences of the spies' actions is that the companies who have the resources and motivation to protect their customers' privacy (the bit software and internet companies — Google, Microsoft, Apple, Facebook, etc.) have been completely compromised. The US spy agencies have forced them to allow access to our data without making their compliance public. They also do this to smaller companies, as Lavabit case demonstrates. Every US provider is now an insecure place to store data by definition (and stand to lose around $10 billion yearly as a result).

What to do?

There are two quite different problems that we might address:

  1. how to prevent powerful agencies like the NSA from compromising our privacy under any circumstances
  2. how to protect most of our data most of the time

These two problems are very different in lots of ways. The brave souls who stand up for human rights in oppressive regimes need 1., of course. But luckily many people are not in such difficult circumstances — in which case the must smaller and more tractable problem of 2. (reasonablely secure privacy much of the time) is what we need.
